column1: #Text=This article is intended to provide the already qualified Scuba diver with information which will help to plan dives in the waters of Mozambique , whether as a local resident or a visitor .
#Text=Information is provided without prejudice , and is not guaranteed accurate or complete .
#Text=Mozambique has a long coastline spread out over the tropical east coat of Africa south of the equator , with several islands on the continental shelf .
#Text=Reef-building corals live where there is suitable substrate and good light – generally where there is no major river mouth nearby .
#Text=The current generally flows north to south , and can be strong .
#Text=This carries turbid water away , and makes drift diving necessary in many places .
#Text=Mozambique has a tropical climate with two seasons , a wet season from October to March and a dry season from April to September .
#Text=Rainfall is heavy along the coast and decreases in the north and south .
#Text=Cyclones are common during the wet season .
#Text=Water temperatures range from 29˚C in summer to 22˚C in winter , and will seldom be below 24˚C .
#Text=People from cooler climates may find winter more comfortable , and there are fewer mosquitos as this is the dry season .
#Text=Visibility can range from 8 – 40 m , depending on the amount of plankton in the water .
#Text=The marine ecology of Mozambique is classified as Tropical Indo-Pacific , which is the most diverse marine ecology known .
#Text=Obviously not all species from this bioregion will be found in all parts of it , but this is an indication of the diversity which can be expected here .
#Text=A wide range of reef building corals , and also other coral types can be found here , along with a diverse invertebrate fauna sharing the shelter and habitat provided by the corals .
#Text=Fish are also represented by a large diversity of species , many of which are particularly colourful .
#Text=Humpback whales can be spotted during their migration from June until November .
#Text=Whale sharks are present all year round and in abundance between November and March .
#Text=giants can reach up to 12m in length and weigh up to 20tonnes .
#Text=Pick up 's can be arranged through lodges , dive centres etc. But there is ample public transport and it is safe and easy to walk to most places in the area .
#Text=Southern Mozambique includes the Municipios of Maputo , Gaza , Inhambane and Sofala from the southern border with South Africa at Ponta d'Ouro north to the Zambesi river .
#Text=Nice coral but known more for its abundance of manta rays , reef sharks , whale sharks and humpback whales .
#Text=They are a PADI dive centre offering all courses from Open Water through to Assistant Instructor and also offer various other watersport activities .
#Text=A small bay just south of Inhambane on a long stretch of sandy coastline .
#Text=The reefs are sedimentary rock with a covering of hard and soft corals and other invertebrates .
#Text=About half way between Inhambane to the south and Vilanculos to the north .
#Text=About one and a half hours from Inhambane by road , and six hours from Maputo .
#Text=Water temperatures about 24°C in winter to 29°C in summer .
#Text=Humpback whales visit from June tyo October .
#Text=Sylvia shoal — about 12 km north of Ponta Morrungulo .
#Text=The shoal is about 14 km long , rising from bottom at about 22m to around 10m on top , with a shallow point at 8m .
#Text=The reef is home to a large variety of nudibranchs , turtles , mantas , rays , eels and sharks
#Text=Aladdin 's Palace — In the middle of Sylvia shoal .
#Text=The reef is about 35m wide , on a sand bottom .
#Text=There is a cleaning station on the seawrd side of the reef which is frequently visited by mantas .
#Text=The reef includestable corals and large crevices , in which large rock lobster can be seen .
#Text=Moray eels also lurk in the cracks , and schools of barracuda and kingfish are often seen above the reef .
#Text=Residents include grouper , potato bass , and turtles .
#Text=Eagle rays , devil rays and white tip sharks are also to be seen .
#Text=Tokyo Drift — Clear water in the Mozambique current .
#Text=Reef with hard and soft corals and a wide variety of reef fish species .
#Text=Also eagle rays , devil rays , and mantas may be seen , and possibly a shark or two .
#Text=Hammerheads , Tiger sharks , Bull sharks and Oceanic black tip sharks have been spotted here .
#Text=New Year reef — A 9 km long reef system south of Sylvia shoal .
#Text=Sherwoods Bookshelf — About 1 km east of the New Years reef system .
#Text=It has a 300m long rocky fault line .
#Text=There are massive green tree corals large numbers of reef fish .
#Text=On the outside of the shoals of reef fish there are often large game fish .

#Text=King Deep — The site is named after the South African underwater photographer , Dennis King , because this is the furthest north that the Tiger Angel Fish , which he identified , has been recorded .
#Text=On the reef there are forests of Green Tree Coral with large numbers of coral fish sheltering from predators such as Kingfish and Barracuda .
#Text=You may also see Potato Bass , Mantas , Sharks , Eagle Rays and other game fish .
